Subject: Re: Ken's Question to Dawkins, Wolpert, and Jones at GECCO 2007
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=163099545; y=pk3IfFpd3mfrVTlvoIlQROCW0LhaN8_HkTsdlh4Iwbyl1VXl9Q_P

First off, I apologize if this is a double post.  It appears that my
previo=
us message did not go through or I may have sent it to the wrong
address.  =
If someone out there has received my previous message
unexpectedly - oops!
=

Ken's initial question of 30,000 genes determining a 1 trillion
connection=
 brain is incomplete.

While there may be around 30,000 genes in our genome=
, don't forget the
central dogma of molecular biology:  DNA -> RNA -> Prote=
in.  Once DNA
is transcribed to RNA, RNA is processed and can result in mul=
tiple
variants which can then lead to subtle differences in the translated
=
proteins.  An example is the Retinoid X Receptors.  On particular
subset, i=
.e. RXR-alpha, has one gene but multiple isoforms resulting
from RNA varian=
ts.  Each of these has subtly different activities with
respect to retinoid=
 binding, DNA specificity, transcriptional control,
etc.  This effectively =
amplifies the number of apparent genes we have.

Also, not all genes are ex=
pressed in all cells.  Cells have somewhat
specific controls over what gene=
s are expressed, to what level they
are expressed, and when they are expres=
sed.  This gives each cell type
a different proteome that specifies that ce=
lls behavior and function.  

Just to add to the complexity, proteins will =
be influenced by the
milieu in which the are present.  For example, tamoxif=
en has been
commonly used as an anti-breast cancer agent due to its ability=
 to
antagonize the estrogen receptor, which is required for growth of some
=
breast cancer tumors.  In cervical cells, however, tamoxifen acts as
an AGO=
NIST.  Based upon the cellular context in which the receptor is
present, ta=
moxifen exhibited different roles.

The fractal analogy used in one of the =
replies is somewhat applicable
and I would extend this to an analogy with S=
teering Behaviors (as
exemplified by Craig Reynolds).  In both these system=
s you have a very
simple set of rules leading to very complex behaviors.  G=
iven the
complexity of protein expression and its role in determining cell
=
behavior, the resulting set of highly complex rules provides a medium
in wh=
ich emergence of brain and mind can occur.

-Kirk




--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "Daniel Tuohy" <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> > > Yes, the answers were=
 indeed lacking. By the way, notice also how
> > > they ignored the second =
part of my question: "How can evolution
> > > search a space of such astron=
omical complexity?"
> 
> I think this question was at least partially addre=
ssed.  Dawkins seems
> to suggest that the genome specifies mechanisms for =
building the
> structure of the brain, and not the structure of the brain i=
tself.  If
> that's the case, then it isn't neccessary to search the space =
of
> possible structures, correct?
> 
> That said, I've thought the same ab=
out the space defined by the genome
> itself.  30,000 genes is 30,000 dimen=
sions, and 4 billion years seems
> like scant time to search it.  Two point=
s which I rely on are (1)
> Generations were occuring much more rapidly for=
 microorganisms (and on
> a much smaller genome), so a billion years is a l=
ong time and (2) The
> search space isn't being searched for, say, a human-=
like solution all
> at once.  Rather, it is searched through gradual comple=
xification, so
> that by the time humans are about to emerge, things like l=
egs, lungs,
> and circulatory systems have already been sorted out.  This i=
s also
> one reason I find NEAT so compelling.
>
